comments.commentBody: I think it's unfair and incorrect to categorize Benn as a workout warrior.  For one, he really wasn't a workout warrior to begin with.  While he ran better during his individual day, he only better 4.57 at the combine where his numbers could be compared in the same setting as his fellow prospects.  You could even put hinm in the Joe Haden group as a guy whose lack of great speed was overlooked.  He did have some impressive measurables, most notably his strength but I don't think anyone thought of him as a rarfied athlete.  But anyway, he deserves a pass for his lack of production.  His quarterback was awful.  You could have imported Jerry Rice from his prime SF days and he would have struggled to put up numbers as well.

Hans:

I think I am ready to capitulate, up to a point. There are, in fact, a couple of distinct alternate strategies that result in the same number of possibilities as the straightforward ordered strategy.

One of them is the one you proposed, where the player concentrates on two of the cups and uses, at most, eight guesses to narrow the choices for those two cups down to two remaining colors (having eliminated the same four colors for both of these cups). At this point, the player can be wrong only one more time in solving the question of which color is under each of these first two cups, bringing the total number of errors to nine, which is the same maximum as if he had followed the ordered strategy and been wrong five times on the first cup and four times on the second.

A variation on this is if the player uses no more than nine wrong guesses to narrow the choices for the first three cups down to three colors. Using your notation, this means that the first nine guesses are of the form (a,b), where a and b are each limited to three choices, e.g., a = 1, 2 and 3, and b = 1, 2 and 3. The player has now divided the puzzle into two separate 3x3 problems. He knows that the numbers 1, 2 and 3 are all in positions 4 through 6, and therefore, the numbers in the first three positions are all greater than 3 (i.e., 4, 5 or 6). Attacking each of these smaller problems in an ordered way, he can be wrong, at most, three times on each, which, added to the nine potential errors already made, again brings the total to 15.

However, I do not agree with the claim that you seem to be making that no matter how the player makes his guesses, he will eventually have enough information to limit the number of reasonable sequences of guesses to 720. This is equivalent to saying that the player cannot possibly make more than 15 errors. I believe that I have already provided examples that show that this is not true. In my worst case example, where the player spreads his guesses across all six possible numbers and all six positions, he can be wrong up to 24 times, without ever making an unreasonable or redundant guess. At that point, he has limited the possibilities for each position to only two numbers (a different pair for each position), and as soon as he knows the correct answer for one of the positions, the rest will fall like dominoes, so he can be wrong only one more time, at worst.

I will generalize this and try to demonstrate what I mean using the simpler 4x4 version of the problem in my next post.

The only way this might work is if the superior airline (Continental) buys and completely takes over the grossly inferior airline (United), jettisons the United management, permeates the Continental culture throughout the entire new airline and retains the well-respected Continental brand.

In spite of all the caricatures of the airline experience, flying on Continental is noticeably different than the experience of flying on the other legacy airlines -- in EVERY aspect. A customer centered merger, which is the only thing that makes sense for the long run for any of these airlines, would bury that once great but now embarrassingly inept United and capitalize on the real and hard-fought achievement of Continental.

If the surviving airline is NOT Continental, then PLEASE forsake this merger.

How can UAL, just in recent memory climbed out of bankruptcy, who does not really have any assets to speak of, consider another financial leap. Heck just the cost of declaring bankruptcy, legal cost, and a weak economy will saddle that company for years too come. Allthough CAL a smaller airline, has some strengths. It for the most part is not overextended, has strong European, carribean and asian routes. With relative labor peace and better performance records as a whole why would you consider teaming up with UAL?

As we look back, the era of Wolfe and Crandall does not look so bad huh fella's?

United has always been at odds with its employees (pilots, flight attendants, mechanics, ramp), but it's incredible how, under Tilton's watch, the airline has developed a total disregard for its customers, even elite frequent flyers.  I've lost count of the customer-unfriendly policies that United has put in place over the past few years.
So what's the round "decision-matic" thing? The picture isn't exactly self-evident.
I have never seen a lamer lyric than the Yankees song. Somewhere Cole Porter is cringing.

Girardi absolutely cost his team the game. He allowed Vazquez to stay in long enough for his team to go from a 3-0 lead to be trailing 5-3.
He should have walked Morales and brought in Robertson to pitch to Rivera. Period.
His hesitancy and the resulting indecision on the part of Marte had to play into his laying a meatball down the heart of the plate.
This game is on Girardii with ample assist from Vazquez & Marte.

Not much thought into this, kinda like the Mets Roster:

Meets the Mess
Meet the Mess
Palm your face and greet the Mets
hide your kiddies
shame your wife
Guaranteed to see a pitcher in strife.

Because the Mets are really suckin’ this year, knocking those dreams right over the wall

Ma -jors
Mi -nors
Every systems falling down
They’re just the M.E.S.S Mess of New York Town

Oh the shortstop, and the catcher and man center field
Where did they go?
Meet the Mess!

Oh, the closer’s looking dour, and third base got no power
Where did they go?

As the mets just fool on down
’cause we’ve got ourselves a shameful club
The Mets of New York town!

Give ‘em a yell!
They need a hand!
And let ‘em know your sufferin’ in the stand!
Come on and meet the Mess
The Republicans are prepared to block financial reform, no matter how weak or flawed.  Do we need a clearer illustration of their position?
I wonder if we'll hear Nancy Pelosi tell the public that the bill needs to be passed in order to see what's in it, like she did with the healthcare bill.

While “the peoples’ ” smartest busy debating, which party is the worse or to blame… your representatives rejoice.

Is anyone in opposition to my view?

The Senate needs to pass the toughest regulations it can on
the financial markets and the instruments that allowed the CEOs of Wall Street to plunder the investments and retirement savings of average Americans. Then the Federal government needs to rid itself of the Bush/Cheney anti-regulation appointees immediately and prosecute the guilty individuals, particularly the CEOs at Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers, etc. who defrauded individual investors, pension funds and municipalities. We should not rest until all of the guilty parties are behind bars.
I just wish the Republicans would fillibuster the financial bill.

Republican Party would be fighting regulation tooth and nail if the Goldman Sachs wasn't indicted. Many will still do their handlers bidding. Unbeilevable! How can any one with a net worth under $10 million vote for these hacks?

Why don't I trust the Democrats with trying to "rush" through a bill. They sure don't seem to have given enough thought to the stimulus, the health care bill and the proposed energy bill. All of them work around a political agenda, not solving problems.

WOW - I think I have it!  When "Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama said on Sunday that his party was still prepared to block debate of the bill as he fought for additional changes, including what he described as tight guarantees against future taxpayer bailouts of banks."  it's code for "we're gonna slow it down and try to kill it like we tried with Health Insurance Reform"....The Wall Street shill Retro-publican party of NO strikes again.

As a very crude rule-of-thumb we could say if Wall Street doesn't want it, it should be made law.
Wall Street is a shell-game, and "derivatives," as seen from its very name, is a major component of a shell game - in this case the "value" of what the buyer is purchasing is "derived" from something else, something hidden away. The perfect con. And criminals on Wall Street have made billions doing this.
All financial dealings should have total transparency and then the supposed theory underlying market capitalism should work; however the fundamental basis of Wall Street is total obfuscation, and that is where they make their (obscene) money.

How come a new york times reporter can admit on the front page of the newspaper and in a book that he committed financial fraud to get a mortgage he couldnt afford and never paid back and Obama isnt upset?

The GOP has made it clear they will fight to protect the Banks by any means necessary. McConnell got campigan donation from Banks to stop Obama from protecting the taxpayers. Many reporters and columnist are also doing their part to lie/spin the truth as they earn the bribe money. As the World leaders close in on the corrupt US Banks the GOP will continue to help the Banks. Now documents, emails have proven the SEC's case as well as the other countries. Foreign Countries will get their money back but the GOP will fight to make sure the US taxpayers wont get a dime of the money stolen from US taxpayers. Senator Graham is blocking Climate change Bill to force Obama to decide which Bill he want most either the Climate or the Finance. To watch elected officials take money from Banks and allow Americans to continue to get robbed is very sad. We see the Tea Party supporting the Banks and fighting the Govenment regulation. One Texas lawyer supported the GOP's effords to block Health Care Bill, but he just found out his daughter has an illness that the Insurance Company will not cover. He said thanks to Obama passing the Health Care Bill, now his daughter can get the medical help she needs. Notice how those who attack Obama learn when it hits their own love ones they think differently.

The Dems will be in for a rude awakening when they try to ram through amnesty when unemployment is 10%. I voted for Obama but I will vote straight GOP if they continue down this path in November, I won't just stay home.

After every major immigration raid Americans line up for those jobs. Why do the Dems think Americans do not deserve jobs?
Can someone please explain to me how and why Lindsey Graham is a Republican?

wasn't this the same tactic the Republicans used to stall the Health Care Reform bill?  I hope the Democrats have learned their lesson and will proceed with the bill Monday to force the Republicans to filibuster and defend Wall Street against re-regulation.  It's their core ideology to keep government from 'overreaching' to stifle free enterprise, but they really don't want to remind the populace of what they stand for in this case.  Let them educate the masses thru their behavior in congress
This proposed legislation is more feel-good than do-good.  It is toothless and is meant only to pander to the emotions of un-sophisticated voters who are accomplished at feeling but not at thinking.

According to figures released on Meet the Press, Sen. Dodd received over $6 million last year from the financial sector. He's retiring this year - undoubtedly to a lucrative consulting job representing Wall Street interests. Depend on him and his well-funded Senate cronies in both parties to produce some overheated flimflam accomplishing nothing and leaving the bad actors, including the Fed and Goldman, at the top of the greed heap, the taxpayers holding the bag and the US government headed toward overt bankruptcy.

Not a word about auditing the Fed, overwhelmingly passed by the House, or investigating the central bank/Morgan/Goldman manipulation of the gold markets as recently heard by the Commodity Futures board, or anything about the phony gold-plated tungsten bars received last fall by the Chinese, apparent source: Fort Knox and the Fed. The Dodd Senate bill actually empowers the Fed even more than presently, and restricts the attempts at transparency in the House bill. That's not going to be good for anybody except the financial elites and their politicians.

Nope, all these characters are going to try to take the money and run and cover their tracks with a lot of meaningless hot air. Any one of them up for reelection this had better get out in front on this with something meaningful, because the public on both the Right and the Left is wise to them at last.
